awd_titl_txt: Summer STEM Teaching Experiences for Undergraduates from Liberal Arts Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a well-documented national need for K-12 teachers with substantial content knowledge in the several STEM disciplines. In this regard, undergraduate STEM majors from liberal arts institutions are an under-tapped pool of potential STEM teachers. The Summer STEM Teaching Experiences for Undergraduates (TEU) program will provide undergraduate STEM majors from liberal arts colleges and universities with an immersive summer experience in secondary mathematics or science education. The TEU program will encourage these students to explore careers in K-12 STEM education via a high quality discipline specific pedagogy course integrated with a teaching practicum with a focus on urban education. Owing to the small size of many liberal arts institutions, a key challenge they face is how to provide their undergraduate STEM students with high quality courses and experiences that are focused on mathematics or science pedagogy. The TEU program is designed to fill this need. The mathematics TEU model has been piloted during the summers of 2013-2015 at Brown University as part of the Brown Summer High School program. Through this TEU project, the mathematics pilot will be joined by the science TEU. The project, led by faculty from Barnard College, Brown University, Bryn Mawr College, Trinity College and Vassar College will contribute to the intent of the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education-EHR effort in adding to the understanding associated with engaging STEM majors from liberal arts institutions in the K-12 enterprise. 

Over five summers, a total of 120 undergraduates (24 per year) will be recruited from a national network of sixty-one liberal arts institutions to take part in the 6-7 week TEU program. Each summer twelve undergraduate students will participate in the mathematics TEU program to be held at Brown University and twelve will participate in the science TEU program to be held at Trinity College. The teaching practicum, designed and taught by the TEU participants working under the supervision of master teacher mentors, will provide a summer enrichment course to approximately 1250 local high-need urban secondary students drawn from the Providence area and from the Hartford Middle Magnet Trinity College Academy. The TEU provides participants with the option to receive credit for the 60 hour pedagogy course. TEU participants will undertake a STEM leadership project at their home institution during the following academic year. TEU project investigators will engage in design and development research to explore the extent to which the TEU model, consisting of an immersive summer experience and teacher leadership project, affects the participants' preparation for teaching. Specific beneficial learner outcomes to be examined include: preservice teacher pedagogical knowledge, efficacy, effectiveness, and leadership. The research will employ a multiple-case study approach and a mixed-effects model to analyze the cumulative data. The data will include pre- and post-tests of participant knowledge of core course content, observational data, surveys and self-assessments collected from all participants, as well as semi-structured interviews and collection of artifacts of teaching from a smaller subset of TEU participants.  What will be learned through the TEU model, and attendant educational research, will provide evidence for wide adoption and will contribute to the broader impacts of this project.

por.por_cntn:
The Summer STEM Teaching Experiences for Undergraduates from Liberal Arts Institutions (TEU) program had as its goal to develop and test a model of a summer program that provides undergraduate STEM majors with an opportunity to explore and deepen their interest in teaching with a like-minded cohort of peers. The model provides an immersive experience integrating a discipline-specific pedagogy course with a supervised teaching practicum and a focus on urban education, together with follow up activities during the academic year.

 The practicum provides STEM enrichment for predominantly high-need secondary students. This is an important component of the TEU program, as the availability of STEM enrichment  opportunities during the summer months can affect student interest and engagement in STEM, boost student achievement, and reduce summer learning loss. The undergraduate TEU interns are mentored and supervised during their practicum by experienced STEM teachers, for whom the mentoring serves as professional development.

The TEU program expanded the opportunities for students at its 61 partner liberal arts institutions to explore careers in K-12 STEM education beyond what their home institutions presently could offer. The program aimed to attract more of these students into careers in STEM education and prepare them to be future leaders in the profession.

 During the first 4 years of the program (pre-COVID) two TEU summer programs were offered annually: Mathematics at Brown University in Rhode Island, and Science at Trinity College in Connecticut. Due to COVID, both programs had to be cancelled in the summer 2020. To compensate, project leadership provided summer 2020 selectees with a partial stipend and a webinar series on STEM teaching topics, which, not surprisingly, met with mixed success. For the summer of 2021, a hybrid version of the TEU program was mounted. The TEU interns were remote, and  thus the pedagogy course and the practicum were taught online. The high school students taking part in the (remote) practicum could earn credit recovery, a new addition to the program.

 There was strong interest in the TEU program. In the six years of TEU programming (2016-2021) an average of 59 applications per year were received for the 24 positions. Applications came  from 55 of the 61 partner institutions and from 27 non-partner institutions.

 Demographic data for the 119 TEU participants in years 1-4 and 6 indicates 20 Asians/South Asians, 8 Hispanics or Latinx, 4 African Americans/Blacks, 1 American Indian or Alaskan Native, and 2 mixed race TEUs. At least sixteen TEUs are the first in their family to attend college, and at least 15 note that the primary language spoken at home is not English.

 Longitudinal data concerning career paths from the first 3 TEU cohorts have been collected (data for the Year 4 cohort were not collected due to COVID) . Sixty-four of the 71 TEUs have responded. Of the 62 who have graduated from college, 30 are currently teaching (4 of whom have earned graduate degrees in STEM education), 12 in high-need schools. Eleven more intend to teach, of whom 4 enrolled in STEM education graduate programs. To date 9 TEU alumni have been awarded Knowles Teacher Fellowships and 2 have been awarded Woodrow Wilson Teaching Fellowships. Data also show that participation in the program positively impacted interns’ interest in teaching and in teaching in high need schools.

 To be in compliance with Section 1405 of Public Law 101-510, it was not possible to extend the award for another year after the COVID-caused cancellations to permit  the projected  fifth in-person TEU program and the planned conference for the final 3 in-person TEU cohorts to be held. Since the statute potentially could affect many Federal grants, the TEU leadership met with several Congressional offices about legislation to suspend enforcement of the statute temporarily due to the pandemic. Every office was sympathetic but Congressional action was not taken. The TEU leadership also inquired about the possibility of NSF using American Rescue Plan funds allocated to the agency, but these funds could not be used for this purpose.

 In accordance with project goals, the TEU leadership team hopes to scale and test the TEU model under a range of conditions. In 2019 and 2020 proposals were submitted to NSF to support the development of five TEU sites across the country. Although both were declined, we are committed to seeking other funding to support these sites. The leadership team already has had success seeking such funding. The Carnegie Corporation of New York has funded a joint American Museum of Natural History/Barnard College TEU site that will be run for the first time in the summer of 2022. This site incorporates two distinctive components into the TEU model: it will be non-residential, drawing TEU participants primarily from CUNY campuses and other New York area institutions, and the practicum will be an official New York Department of Education credit recovery class.

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2021
Modified by: Charles I Steinhorn
por.por_txt_cntn:

The TEU program expanded the opportunities for students at its 61 partner liberal arts institutions to explore careers in K-12 STEM education beyond what their home institutions presently could offer. Although both were declined, we are committed to seeking other funding to support these sites. The leadership team already has had success seeking such funding.
